intro: Thlaspi longiracemosum, commonly known as the long-stemmed whitlow grass, is a flowering plant in the family Brassicaceae. It is characterized by its slender, branching stems and small, white or pale yellow flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant typically grows in moist, disturbed soils and is often found in meadows, roadsides, and along stream banks. It has alternate, linear leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, and its seeds are dispersed by wind. Thlaspi longiracemosum is a herbaceous perennial that plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local pollinator populations.
